turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument next in Number 94 1039, Roy Romer v. Richard G. Evans.
Mr. Tymkovich.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court--
This case involves a challenge to the authority of a State to allocate certain law making power among its State and local governments.
Colorado's Amendment 2 reserves to the State the decision of whether to extend special protections under State law on the basis of homosexual or bisexual conduct or orientation.
The sole question here is whether in this facial challenge that statewide reservation of authority should be nullified under this Court's prior holdings in James v. Valtierra and Hunter v. Erickson.
That question can be authoritatively resolved for two core reasons.
First, the logic and holding of James is indistinguishable and controls here.

Secondly, the rationality of the substantive policy judgment that has so far motivated Congress and other States in deciding not to extend title VII protections or other... to homosexuals and bisexuals similarly supports the decision of Colorado to reserve that question to itself on a statewide basis.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, Mr. Tymkovich--
--It may be, counsel, that we have to reach that question, but it seems to me there is a predicate or a preliminary matter that we ought to discuss at some point during your oral argument.
Usually when we have an equal protection question we measure the objective of the legislature against the class that is adopted, against the statutory classification.
Here, the classification seems to be adopted for its own sake.
I've never seen a case like this.
Is there any precedent that you can cite to the Court where we've upheld a law such as this?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: Your Honor, in James v. Valtierra the Court was presented with a question involving a State constitutional amendment that also identified a classification... in that case, low income persons... and in analyzing the question there, the Court fundamentally looked at whether Hunter v. Erickson should extend beyond the specific racial context in which it was decided.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But the whole point in James was that we knew that it was low income housing, and we could measure the need, the importance, the objectives of the legislature to control low cost housing against the classification that was adopted.
Here, the classification is just adopted for its own sake, with reference to all purposes of the law, so James doesn't work.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: The classification in James did involve a reference to a specific subset of persons, an identifiable group under the theory of the Colorado supreme court.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I know it adopted a theory of a group, but it was with reference to a specific legislative objective... low cost housing.
Here, the classification is adopted to fence out, in the Colorado supreme court's words, the class for all purposes, and I've never seen a statute like that.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: Your Honor, the objective here was to resolve an issue of whether or not to extend special protections to homosexuals and bisexuals, so the issue resolved here--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, Mr. Tymkovich, the language of the amendment I guess has never been actually interpreted by the Colorado courts.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --The Colorado--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Has it been construed or interpreted as yet, in your view?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --Your Honor, this is a facial challenge, and the provision was enjoined before it ever went into effect.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: For bases of this appeal, the Colorado court did make an interpretation that at least to the extent that it preempted local laws and State provisions, that's all the farther it went.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, does it mean that homosexuals are not covered by Colorado's laws of general applicability?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: No, it does not.
In the--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: How do we know that?
I mean, the literal language would indicate that, for example, a public library could refuse to allow books to be borrowed by homosexuals and there would be no relief from that, apparently.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --There are a couple of reasons.

First, in the second opinion of the Colorado supreme court, what I'll call Evans 2, the Colorado supreme court did, in footnote 9 of that opinion, make reference to some general laws of general applicability and found that those would not be displaced by Amendment 2.
Secondly, the--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Does it displace courts in Colorado?
Can a court hear a 1983 case in Colorado--

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --Absolutely.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --dealing with discrimination--

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: Yes, it may.
There--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --if there's a homosexual plaintiff?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --It absolutely changes no provisions under Federal law in access to the court or vindication of one's equal protection rights, nor does it affect the State--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, how do we know that?
I mean, I don't read anything in the opinion that tells me what the thing means.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --The construction that we have offered is well supported by the legislative history and the intent of the proponents.
We think that the law clearly on its face refers to State enactments and State policies and does not displace any Federal law or policy.

The ballot analysis which we presented in our appendix to the petition makes it clear that this was not intended to extend beyond State and local laws, so it's our view that under the Supremacy Clause as well as under a plain interpretation of the amendment, that Federal law would not be disrupted.
Moreover--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Tymkovich, even focusing on State law alone, Federal law is of course supreme.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And as Justice Kennedy pointed out, James v. Valtierra dealt with one issue, low cost housing.
There were dozens of other ways in which to improve the status of the poor, to fight against the blight of poverty.

But here, it's everything... thou shalt not have access to the ordinary legislative process for anything that will improve the condition of this particular group... and I would like to know whether in all of U.S. history there has been any legislation like this that earmarks a group and says, you will not be able to appeal to your State legislature to improve your status.
You will need a constitutional change to do that.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: Your Honor, it's not unprecedented in the sense that it's a preemptive law.

It is unusual to the extent that two strands of the law come together, but the Court's cases have made it clear that it's appropriate to withdraw authority over certain issues from a local level to a higher level of State government.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Tymkovich, what about laws prohibiting bigamy, or prohibiting homosexuality, or homosexual conduct?
Incidentally, how do you interpret the bisexual orientation language, homosexual, lesbian, or bisexual orientation?
Does that require any conduct, or is it just a disposition?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: It's unclear from this text.

However, the reason that that language is in Amendment 2 is because this was a plain response to certain laws that had been enacted by State and local government that used the term bisexual, but it could include either conduct or orientation.
Again, it's unclear how you determine--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I want to know what you mean by... what is meant by... if all orientation means is someone who engages in homosexual, lesbian, or bisexual acts, then you have plenty of precedent in response to your question, namely State laws that absolutely criminalize such activity... bigamy, homosexuality--

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --That's right, the--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Colorado has no law that prohibits consensual homosexual conduct.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --No.
Colorado repealed its sodomy law in 1972, but to answer--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --Justice Scalia's question, it is unclear whether conduct defines the class.
Many courts have so held in looking at the issue of a classification involving--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Are you suggesting--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --You have no position on it?
You have no position on it?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --Yes.
We believe that conduct is the best indicator of--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, is it the sole indicator?
Are you representing to this Court that Colorado's position is that the class defining characteristic is conduct as opposed to preference or proclivity or whatnot?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --No, Your Honor, because that was immaterial to the litigation below.
There was an attempt by the respondents to prove a suspect class--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well then we have to do one of two things.

We have to assume that orientation means something more than conduct, or if there were a serious question, I suppose we would have to send it back and ask the courts of Colorado to tell us, but is there a serious question?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --I don't think that there's a serious question that--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So that orientation means something more than conduct, and we have to assume that in ruling on this challenge, don't we?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --I think that that doesn't change the legal position of the State with respect to this classification.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: May I go back to one point that you have made, and you've made it more than once about the... I guess about the legal position of the State.
You've referred to the issue as the permissibility of withdrawing subject matter from political consideration at a certain level.
You said it has been reserved for a higher level of political action.
It seems to me that there are two things wrong with that characterization.
One of them has already been brought up, and that is, this is not merely a reservation for this particular subject to be dealt with, for example, by statewide referendum.
It is in fact a provision that no law may be made addressing, or addressing for protective purposes this kind of discrimination.
The second thing that seems to me inaccurate about the characterization you're giving us is that this is not merely a reservation of a subject matter.
That is not the subject of the claim.
The claim is that there is a discrimination in the reservation of the subject matter, or a discrimination in the provision for eligibility, or exercise of legislative power.
It seems to me that as you characterize it, it would sound like a due process challenge, but in fact it's an equal protection challenge, because there's a discrimination involved.
Isn't that correct?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: Your Honor, there is a classification involved, but there is no invidious discrimination.
All the fact that the law--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: What does invidious mean?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --I think it means an arbitrary or irrational classification, and that is not the case here.
I think we've shown that there are reasons for the classification.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But in any case, you recognize that this is not the same problem that might be raised if a certain subject matter, e.g., discrimination, were reserved for legislative action at the State level rather than local level.
This is a different problem, isn't it?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: I think it's an equal protection problem, but the question is, does it impinge on a suspect class here--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Right, but it's--

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --or has there been some type of fundamental--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --a different problem from a mere reservation of a broad spectrum of action for political action at one level rather than another.
It's a different problem from that, is it not?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --No, Your Honor, because of the way the lower court has--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, are you saying... I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --has characterized the fundamental right here.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, are you saying then... maybe this is what you're saying, that if the equal protection challenge is in fact recognized or vindicated here, that there is no way to prevent this from in effect ballooning into a due process challenge, that if they win this, then a different kind of claim will also succeed, i.e., a claim that a certain subject matter, discrimination or not, must be dealt with for purposes of Federal law at a certain level of government?
Is that your argument?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
We don't think--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: It's not a slippery slope argument.
You're not saying we go from... if an equal protection challenge wins here, a due process challenge necessarily wins too.
You're not saying that.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --There's been no due process challenge in this case--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But that's not what you're arguing.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --and there is--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But that's not what you're arguing, is that--

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --That's correct.
There is a slippery--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --But you said the ban extends to State legislation as well as to local legislation here.
It's not a question of who can do it, but the State itself can't do it through the ordinary legislative process.
It will take a constitutional change.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --Well, the initiative is the ordinary political process in our State.
We've had many repeals in other substantive matters on our statewide ballot.
We had four on the... four repeal measures on the ballot the same year that Amendment 2 was enacted.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Tymkovich, I was trying to think of something comparable to this, and what occurred to me is that this political means of going at the local level first is familiar in American politics.
In fact, it was the way that the suffragists worked.

When they were unable to achieve the vote statewide, they did it on a cities first approach, and I take it from what you are arguing that if there had been a referendum that said no local ordinance can give women the vote, that that would have been constitutional.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
I think that that--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: What's the difference?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --classification would be analyzed under this Court's equal protection jurisprudence on a suspect--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, cast your mind back to the days before the Nineteenth Amendment.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --I think the Court would apply the traditional equal protection analysis and--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And what would have happened?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --They would have determined whether or not there was a fundamental right to vote that had been impinged on or was--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But there was no right to vote for women.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --Right, or under the Fourteenth Amendment, or whether women were a suspect class entitled to some heightened scrutiny in the circumstances.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And if they weren't?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: If they weren't, the Court would--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Then it would have been constitutional.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --enact a rational basis type of review.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Yes, and that's what you're urging here.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: Yes.
We're urging for this classification, that the Court engage in a rational basis type of review.
No court has found homosexual orientation or conduct to be a suspect classification.
Therefore, the traditional equal protection model should be applied in this case.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Tymkovich, what is now required under Colorado law, assuming that the constitutionality of this is upheld, in order to change that provision?
It would be what, a statewide referendum?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: That's right, Your Honor.

There would be an initiative, or a referred measure from our State legislature, and it would be placed on the ballot in the same fashion that the Amendment 2 was placed on the ballot in the first instance, so there would be that mere opportunity for the opponents of Amendment 2, just like there were for the proponents.

And to further answer Justice Ginsburg's question, what the respondents here are saying is that those who oppose certain type of special protections here cannot get their policy preference vindicated through the legislative process unless they are able to successfully preempt or repeal such laws at the local level.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: When you talk about special protection, this brings me back to an earlier question about discrimination in libraries.
What... how do you interpret the term, minority status quota preferences protected status?
You mean... what does that mean?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: Protected status would be a particular affirmative positive piece of legislation that granted some type of protection--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Special protection beyond what--

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --Beyond the Fourteenth Amendment baseline.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --So why wouldn't that have been your answer to the library hypothetical that was produced earlier?
Any... no homosexual can be treated differently from other people.
He simply cannot be given special protection by reason of that status.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: That's right.
Amendment 2 is simply a Fourteenth Amendment--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask how that works in the public accommodation area?
If a hotel or a restaurant... at common law you get some kind of an innkeeper's duty to take everybody in.
Could an innkeeper refuse accommodations to a homosexual who was not engaging in any homosexual conduct but had admitted that he had that type of tendency?
Could an innkeeper under... in Colorado just say, I'm sorry, we don't rent rooms to people like you?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --To the extent there was some tort law of general applicability in those circumstances about innkeeper's duty, we don't think that Amendment 2 would knock that out.
To the extent--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So you would say the public accommodations protection is still available to homosexuals.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --Amendment 2 would carve out any special protections in the public accommodation area that had been extended to homosexuals--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What would the rule be in Colorado?
How do you understand the law there?
Now, would a homosexual have a right to be served in a restaurant?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --A homosexual would not have any claim of discrimination or special liability theory in a private setting after Amendment 2.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Even in the public accommodation area.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: Unless the Court... and again, we haven't had a full construction of Amendment 2 yet from our State courts.
Unless a State court construed the innkeeper's duty to be a law of general applicability to--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Do you know what the law of Colorado is on that point?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --I do not.
I have not encountered that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So we don't know whether homosexuals have a right to be served or not.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: That will be a question for the State courts interpreting Amendment 2.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But if they do have a right to be served, would that be an affirmative right, then, as in the distinction Justice Scalia was drawing, or would that be just being treated like everybody else?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: I think it would be treated just like any other characteristic or classification that has not gotten the special benefits of the civil rights law.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And being... having the right not to be refused a job or to rent on that ground is a special right.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: Unless--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It's not being just like everybody else.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --That would bring it into the range of private choice and private arrangements, unless there is some particular law that would disable that ability by private--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But there can't be such a particular law in Colorado.
I don't understand.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --Unless Amendment 2 is repealed, or there is some general provision that might apply.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And one last question.
What is the rational basis for this statute?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: The purpose of this statute was to preempt State and local laws that extended special protections.
It was a response to political activism by a political group that wanted to seek special affirmative protections under the law.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, it went farther, because there were political groups that had already... as I understand it, Aspen had a protective statute of some kind.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And it's... what is the rational basis for the people outside of Aspen telling the people in Aspen they cannot have that statute?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: Amendment 2 covers a range of circumstances, not just the preemption of the local ordinances, but it did do that.
It also served as a--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What is the rational basis for the people outside of Aspen telling the people in Aspen they cannot have this nondiscriminatory provision?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --The rationale is any law of general preemption that wants to make a substantive decision, and the people here, the rational basis for that substantive decision in our view was a political response to what the people might have perceived as laws going too far or being too intrusive.
What this does is--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, the State of Virginia has a very broad State preemption doctrine.
Local governments do not have the power in Virginia that they do in many other places.
I suppose the rational basis for that is just that the people generally would prefer to have the rules set by the State at large rather than by local governments.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor, and there's nothing wrong, especially in this area of civil rights and statewide protections, in making that an issue of statewide concern, and that's simply what Colorado was--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But Mr. Tymkovich, doesn't that go back to the problem I tried to raise earlier?

You're saying that as a general matter certain laws can be determined as subject to action at one political level and not at others, but isn't the question here is, what is the rational basis for determining that affirmative protection for homosexuals cannot be dealt with at a certain level, whereas affirmative protection for the aged, for the handicapped, and so on, can be?
Isn't that what the rational basis has to address, and how does your answer to Justice Stevens address it?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --Your Honor, that's a quintessential political judgment on how you provide relative protection to relative groups.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, it's a judgment that is made politically, but that doesn't state a rational basis.

I mean, if we were saying... if we were asking you this question, why should discrimination be dealt with in Colorado at the State level rather than the local level, or at the constitutional level, or whatnot, is that a denial of any constitutional right, and you said, no, that's a political choice.
Colorado... the people of Colorado can decide what level to deal with this problem.
That would, it seems to me, answer a substantive due process challenge, but that's not the question that's being asked here.

The question that's being asked here is, why is discrimination against one group dealt with under State law differently from discrimination against other groups, and your rational basis answer, it seems to me, has got to go to a justification for the classification.
It isn't enough simply to say, oh, well, that's what politics decided.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: Your Honor, that's not my response.
I think there are some particular discrete reasons also, and this is to answer Justice Ginsburg's question also.
This issue was seen as particularly desirable for a statewide uniform determination.

There's a question about the desirability of each local jurisdiction dealing with this issue, which I think raises some very fundamental and sensitive cultural, moral, political concerns for our State.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, it does, but are you getting any further than simply the answer, that's what they wanted, that's the result of the political process?
I don't see in your answer the kind of justification independent merely of majority will, which an equal protection classification question calls for.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: Your Honor, in addition to statewide uniformity, we've also advanced some reasons that show how Amendment 2 advances other liberty interests, and there are competing liberty interests that are, in fact--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: What's the liberty interest that it advances?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --It promotes a zone of autonomy.

The State supreme court and the trial court found that religious liberty interests were advanced here, associational liberties were advanced here, and the Court simply made a determination below that they were not narrowly tailored, so--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Tymkovich, if this is an ordinary equal protection challenge and there's no heightened scrutiny, isn't it an adequate answer to Justice Souter's question to say this is the only area in which we've had a problem?
If localities started passing special laws giving favored treatment to people with blue eyes, we might have a statewide referendum on that as well?
Isn't one step at a time a normal response to equal protection?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --That's exactly what happened here, and the court--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, what is the problem?
I mean, what is the problem that you supposedly have been having?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --I think the problem that the voters saw, they were presented with an opportunity to preempt and make a decision at a statewide level for laws that raise particular and sensitive liberty concerns.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: State... State subdivisions giving preferences which the majority of the people in the State did not think desirable for social reasons, isn't that the problem that was seen?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And if they should start giving preferences for some other reason that the majority of the State did not consider desirable... let's say, bigamy, special preferences to bigamist couples, there would be a law on that subject as well.
Isn't your answer, this is the only area where the people apparently saw a problem, which is enough for equal protection?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: It is, and this is an area where there have been piecemeal additions of special protections.
We've had--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What is the special preference at stake here?
What is the special preference that a homosexual gets?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --I think it creates a cause of action on the basis of the characteristic that's not available to the general population at large.
Homosexuals are entitled to every other protection of the civil rights laws, the criminal laws, the--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: You've just said that in... apart from whatever the common law might be, with this ordinance on... with this amendment on the books, a restaurant owner can say, sorry, I don't want to serve gay people, and what about... take a scarce resource.

Think of a public hospital that has a kidney dialysis machine, and the hospital says, we have to limit this, and one group that we're going to keep out, we're not going to have any gay, any lesbian person use this... use this facility.
Now, there would be, under this amendment, what recourse?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --Well, first of all there's Federal law that may preempt, and secondly, there is an opportunity, as we construe Amendment 2, for the State to enact a policy that would treat all citizens the same in those circumstances rather than carve out a special--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But let's just have the law as it is right now.
There's a scarce resource.
There's a basis... there has to be some rules about who can use it and who can't.
That's the rule that the public hospital sets.
Under this amendment, that's okay, right?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --In this facial challenge, we don't know how the court is going to construe other potentially applicable State laws.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: How... I do have one question on that point which I'd like to ask.
The statute says, no agency shall adopt or enforce any policy whereby homosexual conduct, or whatever, orientation, shall be the basis of any claim of discrimination.
So if a police department says, there's been a lot of gay bashing.
It's our policy.
Stop it.
If the head librarian says, you're making gays sit... you're being mean to them and not letting them in.
If the health department says the same thing, if the insurance commissioner says the same thing, doesn't this word policy cover that, and if it doesn't cover it, what is it about?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: The government agencies that you've indicated could enact a general nonbias policy or require--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No, no.
What they say is, they put up regulation 14.2.
There's been gay bashing here.
Stop it.
They put it more politely, but that's what they mean.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --Amendment 2 would not prohibit that.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: It would not prohibit that.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: It would not prohibit--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Then what does the word policy prohibit?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --Policy prohibits the enactment of some special entitlement--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No, but give me an example.
What could it possibly be?
What is policy, if it isn't the policy of the department saying, do not discriminate against gays?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Tymkovich, I assume in your State you're not allowed to bash nongays either, are you?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --No.
The criminal law is--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So prohibiting the bashing of gays would not be a special protection, would it?
It would just be enforcing the general law.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --Yes, and Amendment 2 does nothing to restrict the applicable--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Isn't that the response to Justice--
--But does it--

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --That's right.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --Fine.
[Laughter]
But does it prevent... what... give me an example of what it prevents.

Does it prevent the police department, the librarian, the dozens of State agencies from putting up a piece of paper that says, policy it is our policy in this department not to discriminate against gays.
You're saying it doesn't prohibit that.
Then what does it prohibit?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: It prohibits any type of special protection or a liability claim that somebody might have under that policy.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: It seems to me that your answer is inconsistent to what the supreme court of Colorado said.
It said health insurance discrimination regulations are void.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: The health--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: That's... based on sexual orientation.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --The health... that regulation did carve out what would be construed as special protection--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: That's inconsistent with the answer you gave to Justice Breyer.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --I don't think so, Your Honor, because I thought he was talking about a law of general applica--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No.
Look, suppose Boulder, Colorado says, it is our policy in Boulder not to discriminate against gays.
They call it Boulder Regulation 14.2.
Is that forbidden by this?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --Yes, it would to the extent--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right.
Now, suppose the police department does exactly the same thing.
Is that forbidden by this?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --The police department would be governed by a rule of general applica--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So the police department--

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --They would not be able to--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --I don't understand.
So is the city of Colorado.
They're all governed by, they can't discriminate arbitrarily.
My point is, suppose that the police department says exactly the same thing.
You say that's not forbidden.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --That's correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: Your Honor, may I reserve the balance of my time for rebuttal?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes.
Thank you, Mr. Tymkovich.
Ms. Dubofsky, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court--
Let me begin with how Amendment 2 should be construed and then discuss how our legal theories relate to its unique combination of breadth and selectivity.

Amendment 2 is vertically broad in that it prohibits all levels of government in the State of Colorado from ever providing any opportunity for one to seek protection from discrimination on the basis of gay orientation.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, when you say all levels of government in Colorado, Ms. Dubofsky, you don't include the people by referendum, I take it, or the people by initiative.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: No, we do not.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And I have one more very specific question.
What about the courts?
Can the courts interpret a statute that prohibits unreasonable denial of public accommodations to include gays by a specific judgment that--

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: The--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --deals with the rights of gay people?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --The State has conceded that Amendment 2 is unconstitutional to the degree it would prohibit such a claim based upon Federal law since 1983.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: No, no, no, I meant State courts interpreting State public accommodation laws.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Our theory is that Amendment 2 on its face prohibits a State court from recognizing such a claim, but that particular interpretation of the amendment is not necessary for this Court to find that Amendment 2 is unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Thank you, and that particular interpretation has not been given by the supreme court of Colorado.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: It has not.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: That's right.
The Colorado supreme court interpreted the amendment, and it said it was doing this as a minimum, because that was all that was necessary in order to find the amendment unconstitutional.

It interpreted the amendment to mean that State and local governments are barred from promulgating and enforcing rules that declare discrimination against gay people by both government and private actors to be arbitrary, so that would include Justice Breyer's general policy suggestion with respect to the police department.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: What do we do about, counsel for the other side said, no, it doesn't forbid the police department from having a rule saying don't discriminate against gays.
It doesn't forbid any of these agencies from having such a rule.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: The Colorado supreme court interpretation of this amendment is authoritative for purposes of this argument, I believe, and the Colorado supreme court--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Where does it say that in the Colorado supreme court's opinion?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --It says that on page B 3, D 24--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Of the white appendix, or the--

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --Yes, in the white appendix.
B 3, D 24, and D 25.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --D as in does?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: D as in David, or does, yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: David, yes.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: And the way in which the Colorado supreme court says that is by giving examples of the types of provisions that would be repealed by the amendment, or precluded from enactment in the future.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What does it say on B 3 that says that?
Is it B--
--It... B 3... you said B as in--

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: B as in boy.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Boy.
It seems to me it says the effect, the ultimate effect is to prohibit any government entity from adopting similar or more protective statutes, regulations, or orders in the future.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Yes, and it refers back to the first sentence.
It says, the immediate objective of Amendment 2 is at a minimum to repeal existing statutes, regulations, ordinances, and policies.
Then on pages--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Wait, that barred discrimination based on sexual orientation.
I assume that that means special provisions giving special protection--

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --as opposed to a general law that says you have to, not just accept homosexuals, but all citizens have to be accommodated at hotels.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --That's correct.
There are general laws that say--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: As opposed to a special law that says a private homeowner who wants to rent a room... you know, the mom and a family that wants to do bed and breakfast cannot discriminate in the people it accepts.
Although it has no obligation to take the public at large, it can decide to take only Irishmen if it wants, but it cannot discriminate on the basis of homosexuality.
I thought that's the kind of thought the court is referring to here.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --The Colorado supreme court is referring to?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: No, I don't think so.

I think it's referring to the general ordinances that were preempted by Amendment 2, and in Colorado those general ordinances either have specific exceptions for exactly the type of example you gave, or they have never been enforced to have someone in the Mrs. Murphy's boardinghouse situation required to accept someone who does--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You mean no general laws can be applied to homosexuals now?
They can be bashed, they can be murdered, they... all sorts of things.
Is that what it means?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --We think it can mean that, but we don't think the Colorado supreme court found it necessary to go that far in its interpretation--

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --and we're not arguing that it needs to be interpreted that broadly in order to find Amendment 2 unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --I don't think the Colorado supreme court did interpret it that broadly.
I think they interpreted it to refer to special protections accorded to homosexuals and not to the public at large.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: I think we're having trouble a little bit with semantics.
One of the difficulties is the use of the words special protection in this case.
I don't think there is such a thing as special rights or special protections.
I think there's a right which everyone has to be free from arbitrary discrimination.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: No, but if I go and ask a homeowner to take me in on bed and breakfast and the homeowner says, I don't like Italians, that's my tough luck, unless there's a law against it.
It's that person's house, and that person is entitled not to like Italians and not to rent rooms to Italians.

That's fine, unless there's a law against it, and you can have such a law prohibiting the rental of rooms, or refusal to rental on the basis of racial discrimination or on the basis of homosexuality, if you want to make that a category, and I think that this law says, no special protection on that basis.
Why isn't that a special protection, one that is not given to everyone?

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: At D 24 and D 25 there's some particular examples.
Wasn't that--

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: That's right, D 24--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --Colleges, State colleges, the insurance example.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --That's right.
That's right, and all of those particular laws say that there shall be no discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.
They apply to everyone.
They're laws of general applicability.
Amendment 2 preempts those laws, or precludes or bars those laws only on the basis that they provide protection for people on the basis of gay sexual orientation.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Yes, but you... but they are laws that provide special protection for that particular category of person, which they don't provide to people at large.
You can refuse to hire someone because you don't like the way he combs his hair.
There's no law that says combing of hair is not a proper basis of discrimination.
If you don't like that, you can refuse to hire him.
Special protection is given by this law which they cite by reason of homosexual orientation or conduct.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Well, in Colorado--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Is that not special?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --In Colorado, there is a law which says one cannot be terminated from employment for any legal off duty conduct, and gives one the basis for a claim.
If your employer doesn't like the way you comb your hair, that was an improper reason for terminating your employment.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Does a State college... can a State university decide not to admit a student under generally applicable law because it doesn't like the way he combs his hair?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: That's a question I'm not sure I know the answer to, but I think--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I mean, can State universities discriminate arbitrarily?
Can State insurance commissioners discriminate arbitrarily?
I would assume not.
I mean--

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --I don't think they can discriminate arbitrarily, no.
They shouldn't be able to.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --Let me put it to you this way.
Suppose there's a Colorado ordinance, or city ordinance which said you cannot bar people from public accommodations for any arbitrary or unreasonable reason.

Could a court in Colorado find that barring... after this amendment, could a court in Colorado find that it was unreasonable or arbitrary to bar a person from public accommodations by reason of sexual orientation?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: I think a court could find that, yes.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Despite the provision under the Constitution that says no preferences should be given?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Well, it depends upon whether the court is referring to more general equal protection law on a Federal level.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: No, no.
It's talking about interpreting a statute that says you cannot deny for an arbitrary or unreasonable... on the basis of an arbitrary unreasonable criterion.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: If that criteria in the particular case is because the person who was denied that benefit is a gay person, then I think under Amendment 2 the court would not be able to provide relief.
Now, we don't think that this Court needs to resolve that type of a specific issue, the application of Amendment 2, in order to find Amendment 2 unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But isn't the very purpose of this ordinance to say, it's not arbitrary to leave out of a catalog of protection against discrimination, it's not arbitrary to leave out homosexual, lesbian... persons of homosexual, lesbian, or bisexual orientation?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Amendment 2 if interpreted at its broadest would authorize that type of discrimination.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But even on a narrower interpretation, even for example if Amendment 2 didn't touch courts, wouldn't it be very difficult for the courts of Colorado to say that that was an irrational or an arbitrary basis for discrimination with Amendment 2 on the books, even if Amendment 2 was narrowly construed?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Yes, it would be, I believe--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --and we argue in our brief that Amendment 2 would prevent a court from providing a remedy in these circumstances.
We think it does on its face.
However, the Colorado supreme court--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Because it refers to departments of the government.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --Absolutely.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: But the Colorado supreme court didn't think it was necessary to go that far in order to find the amendment unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, we really don't have a definitive interpretation, I guess, of how far this amendment would go.
I think the arguments and responses this morning are illustrative of the fact that we're not sure.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: I think we do have a definitive interpretation from the Colorado supreme court.
It's at pages D 25 and D 24, actually--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --and that's where the Court--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: I looked at that, and I just thought that that wasn't definitive.
There are still questions about how far it would go and the extent to which it reaches courts, and so forth and so on.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --One of the difficulties with this amendment is that you have no idea what type of general rule might be necessary in the future to prevent arbitrary discrimination against gay people.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, isn't it your position, Ms. Dubofsky, that you can sustain the Colorado supreme court's decision overthrowing the statute by taking just what the Colorado supreme court said was the minimum meaning?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Yes, that's correct.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And so you don't have to get beyond that, in your view, in order to uphold your position.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And this is a facial challenge.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: And this is a facial challenge, that's right.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Which means that you take the position that there are no applications in which the statute can be constitutional.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Well, we would here because we think the minimal interpretation here is sufficient to find the amendment unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Which means there are no applications that would be constitutional.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: It doesn't necessarily mean that there are no applications that would be constitutional.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I think it does if it--

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: It just means that those are irrelevant.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Well, that's not what our case law involving facial challenges says.

If you wanted to wait for an as applied challenge, you might pick an unconstitutional situation and litigate that, but when you challenge it on your... on its face, you are saying that in all of its applications it is invalid.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: We're saying that the minimal interpretation that the Colorado supreme court gave to this in all of its applications is invalid.
Because there may be other types of applications of this amendment, we don't have to deal with those in this particular facial challenge because they're basically irrelevant.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Ms. Dubofsky, do I understand correctly that what you're saying about what the Colorado supreme court said, at a minimum this amendment immediately repeals all of the laws that are listed, and this group of people cannot be reinstated into this group of laws without a constitutional amendment, and that is what you say is unconstitutional--

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Or--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --under Federal equal protection?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --Or any other laws of general prophylactic rules.

There's a difference between general prophylactic rules that prevent arbitrary discrimination such as the rules or statutes that are listed there, but that's not an exhaustive list, and the application or, you know, case by case determination of whether a particular denial of admission to a hotel, let's say, is covered by Amendment 2.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But these rules on 24 and 25 don't, as I understand them, prohibit arbitrary discrimination.
They prohibit discrimination just on particular grounds... race, sex, homosexual orientation, not how you comb your hair.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: No, they... it's not homosexual orientation, it's sexual orientation in general.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Ah.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: The laws that Amendment 2 deals with, all are laws that apply to everyone.
Amendment 2 only--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They do apply to everyone, but they only apply for certain reasons.
They are not laws that say, no arbitrary discrimination.
You can discriminate on very arbitrary bases, just not those particular bases listed.
Isn't that right?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --That could be right.
It depends upon the circumstance.

But what I'm really trying to point out is that rules such as general... the Boulder ordinance, let's say, or the State insurance statute, presume that certain types of discrimination can be arbitrary.
They're general prophylactic rules.
Most of our civil rights laws in this country are effectively enforced by general prophylactic rules.
If we had to rely on an individual case by case enforcement, I don't think we'd have very much civil rights law enforcement.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Is there a principle in Colorado law, as in many laws... let me explain what I'm thinking... simply that if a private person can often act arbitrarily, often, and you tell that person that they can't discriminate against gays, you've given gays a special protection, all right, but governments by and large cannot act arbitrarily anyway.
Is there such a principle in Colorado law?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Yes, there is.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Is there an administrative procedures act, for example, in Colorado?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Yes.
There's generally a principle that government cannot act in an arbitrary fashion, that governmental services are available to everyone.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So that's why you say, or you think the Colorado supreme court is saying that this law or policy, if it means anything, means that Colorado cannot enforce that nonarbitrary principle anyway through rules and regulations.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Let me ask you, counsel, getting away from the wording in the provisions of this amendment, suppose that Colorado is concerned that one city has passed an ordinance giving preference to gays in employment hiring, and for any number of reasons the citizens of Colorado do not want that.
Some people say they want uniform laws because it's easier on employers.
Could the citizens of Colorado by referendum repeal that ordinance?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Yes, they could repeal that ordinance.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Without any constitutional objection?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: I think that's correct.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Could they also provide that no such ordinance shall be adopted in the future?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: That's where it gets more difficult.

That's where our political participation argument comes to play, that by disabling a government from responding to a need for a particular benefit, the type of protection that... it depends upon the circumstances.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, it would seem a little odd that there could be an ordinance enacted, then repealed by the referendum, then the ordinance is enacted again, then repealed... it just goes back and forth.
That seems a little odd.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Ms. Dubofsky, could Colorado adopt a law that says any law in our State dealing with discrimination on any ground has to be passed at the State level?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: It could.
The problem--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: That would be valid.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --Well, it may be.
There are other problems with dealing with civil rights protections and generally, but let's say they passed Amendment 2 but it didn't target gay people.
It simply said that no one can obtain any protection from discrimination, arbitrary discrimination for any reason.
That would not present the problem that Amendment 2 presents.
Amendment 2 is very selective.
It targets only one group of people, and that's where it encounters equal protection difficulties.
The State may be able to rearrange its process in any number of ways.
It just can't do it in a way that prevents one particular group.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Ms.--
--But the... I'm sorry.
Go on.
No.
That's all right.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What group does it target?
I'm asking you the same question I asked the Attorney General.
How do you read the statute when it refers to sexual orientation, homosexual, lesbian, or bisexual orientation, conduct, practices, or relationships?

Suppose a person who, let's say, has a tendency to homosexual conduct, but has never engaged in homosexual conduct, is that person... would an ordinance that relates to that person be covered by this?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Yes.
The Colorado supreme court did interpret this initiative in this regard.
It said that homosexual conduct was subsumed within homosexual orientation, and--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, I'm sure it is, but what else?
I mean, that's the problem.
What else?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --I don't understand what you mean by what else.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Beyond homosexual conduct.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Well, heterosexual people are not identified exclusively by heterosexual conduct.
In the same fashion, homosexual people are not defined exclusively by homosexual conduct.
It doesn't mean that heterosexual people don't have a heterosexual orientation.
Homosexual people have a homosexual orientation.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, are you saying, then, that orientation identifies a group beyond the identification of... by reference to specific homosexual conduct?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Yes, it does.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.
So it's a broader category.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: And that's what the Colorado supreme court--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Both words are used... both words are used in the amendment.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --Both words are used in the amendment, but the Colorado supreme court said that homosexual orientation is broader than homosexual conduct and that... the State had been arguing that, well, we'll just sever out the language, homosexual orientation, from Amendment 2.
The Colorado supreme court said no, you can't sever this amendment--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, what if I thought that there's a problem with orientation but not a problem with the others, do you win or lose on this facial challenge?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --If you thought there was a problem with targeting people based on their homosexual--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --orientation, people who do not engage in conduct of the sort, but have a tendency in that direction.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --Well, I'm not quite sure what you mean by problem.
Do you mean--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Suppose I find that it would be valid to have such a law directed at conduct--

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --but not at... directed at something other than conduct.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: No, we don't lose, because this law's--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why don't you lose?
This is a facial challenge.
You say it has no valid applications.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --This law is much broader than that, and the minimal interpretation given by the Colorado supreme court is that the law covers homosexual orientation as well as conduct, and that they are not severable.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well--
--But isn't the breadth that you would rely on not that it covers orientation rather than just conduct, but that it in effect fences people out of a political process?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And I guess that takes me back to your answer to, I guess it was Justice O'Connor, in which you said the constitutional defect was the manner in which, or a general constitutional defect would be targeting homosexuals.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: That's not really your position, is it, because if there were an ordinance... let's say there were an ordinance in a given city saying there will be no discrimination based on age, handicap, or sexual orientation, and there were a political move in that city to repeal the reference to sexual orientation, that would be targeted at homosexuals, but it would not run afoul of what I understand your position to be here, is that correct?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: I'm not certain I understand what you're driving at.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Look, if... you've got an ordinance in a city that says no discrimination based on age, handicap, or sexual orientation.
There's a political move in the city to repeal the reference to sexual orientation.
It succeeds.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Is that a violation of equal protection?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Ms. Dubofsky, supposing that in Colorado, shortly before the enactment of this ordinance, there had been agitation, say, by dissident Mormon sects to repeal the prohibition against polygamy that I assume Colorado has, and so there's a referendum that says... the Colorado constitution says polygamy will always be a felony in the State of Colorado, now, does that fence out these people who would like to see polygamy allowed?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Not necessarily, because that's really dealing with much more of a discrete issue.
It's not a restructuring of the political process.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But there... well, there... it's certainly restructured, if they were agitating before the legislature to try to get a prohibition against polygamy repealed.
It certainly fences them out there.
They now have to go to a referendum just like your clients do.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: That's correct, but the particular issue involved is having to do with the identity of the group of people who are engaging in polygamy, and it's prohibiting polygamy.
The best way I can answer that question is to say, if you substituted bigamists or polygamists into the language of Amendment 2, then you would have a problem, as we point out, but here--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What sort of a problem would you have?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --You would have a problem of denying people the fundamental right to participate in the political process.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, so then you say that Colorado cannot say in its constitution either polygamy or bigamy will always be a felony.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: They could say that in their constitution, yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, would it be valid, under your theory of the Federal Constitution?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: To have that in the--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --Colorado constitution?
Yes, it would.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well then, why is that different from this case?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: That is different from this case because this case is targeting a particular group of people on a personal characteristic, and--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but surely the dissident sects that want to practice polygamy are a particular group of people, too.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --That's correct.
What they're not being deprived of is a whole category of laws that provide them a benefit, the opportunity to seek protection from discrimination or a similar--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but maybe this is essential to their religion.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --Well, then it would come under a whole different way of analyzing the issue, and that would be whether it deprived them of a First Amendment--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Ms. Dubofsky, do you contend that... are you asking us to overrule Bowers v. Hardwick?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --No, I am not.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, there we said that you could make homosexual conduct criminal.
