Why can a State not take a step short of that and say, we're not going to make it criminal, but on the other hand, we certainly don't want to encourage it, and therefore we will neither have a State law giving it special protection, nor will we allow any municipalities to give it special protection.
It seems to me the legitimacy of the one follows from the legitimacy of the other.
If you can criminalize it, surely you can take that latter step, can't you?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: What you've done is deprived people, based on their homosexual orientation, of a whole opportunity to seek protection from discrimination, which is a very different thing.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So do you do it when you throw them in jail for a felony?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: No--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I'm not talking about orientation, now.
I'm talking about conduct.
If we have held it constitutional to make the conduct criminal, how could it be unconstitutional to go so much short of that?
We don't want to get into the hassle of intrusion into private life, and all of that, that that requires.
We're not going to criminalize it.
On the other hand, we do not think it is conduct that ought to be encouraged, and therefore we will not allow any special protections for it, neither at the State level, nor locally.
Doesn't... if the one is constitutional, must not the other one be?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --If homosexuals were put into the language of Amendment 2 only in terms of, those people who engage in homosexual conduct shall not be entitled to ever seek protection under the civil rights laws, we would say that is unconstitutional.
That's a very different thing from saying that you can criminalize homosexual sodomy.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But isn't it also true that this law applies to this class of people even if they abstain from the prohibited conduct?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: That's correct, and it also could apply to people who aren't gay, but who may be perceived to be gay and are discriminated against on that basis.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Ms. Dubofsky, if we could go back to the question Justice Kennedy was asking, I take it your answer to him was, your objection is to the permanency, the bar to access to the political process to get something changed.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But you're not objecting to the State saying, we repeal all existing ordinances.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: That's correct, and that's because the case law and the fundamental right to political participation says a simple repealer is all right.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Then how do you answer Justice Kennedy's further question, well, isn't the State entitled to end a ping pong game?
The locality passes it, the State repeals it.
The locality passes it again, the State repeals it again.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: The constitutional bar, in effect, to ever adopting a protection of any sort, or an opportunity to seek protection from discrimination, is a very different type of barrier than a simple repealer and reenactment, because it means that if the group is going to ever obtain any protection, it has to amend the State constitution first.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yes, but wouldn't you say that it could end the ping pong ball that way if it ends it with respect to all protection against private discrimination?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: That's correct, it could.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: That would not be an equal protection problem.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So you're saying, if I understand you, you just can't end the ping pong ball for this particular group.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: That's correct, or any particular group.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: It doesn't matter who the group is--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --you just can't do it this way.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But you can end the game.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: That's correct, you can end the game.
If the State wants to repeal and prohibit any civil rights protections for anybody at any level of the government in the future, and do it for everyone--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask you a rather elementary question I should know?
Did the State file an answer in this case?

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: --Did the State file an answer in this case?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: They did file an answer.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I couldn't find it--

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: And we tried the case.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Thank you, Ms. Dubofsky.

turn.speaker: jean_e_dubofsky
turn.label: Ms. Jean E. Dubofsky
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Tymkovich, you have 1 minute remaining.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: Your Honor, the Colorado supreme court rule basically holds that preemption is unconstitutional.
It says that with respect to this issue... this issue, not the people.
This issue... it must be resolved at the local level, and that people who oppose the substantive policy--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, excuse me, I don't see where it said preemption was unconstitutional, as distinct from saying, preemption for one identifiable group was unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --It's preemption of this issue that affects a group, and in James the Court told us it's permissible--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, it doesn't... it doesn't... the ordinance speaks both in terms of issue, i.e., basis for claim, and group.
I mean, it refers to both, doesn't it?
You can't have one without the other, the way the ordinance is--

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --It's an issue that affects a group, like in James, and like in Gregory v. Ashcroft, where we had an age restriction in the State.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --Well, isn't in effect defined in terms of the group under traditional equal protection analysis, which looks to the intent of the enacting body?

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: Right, and then there would be the question--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: --of whether a rational basis supports that.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr.--

turn.speaker: timothy_m_tymkovich
turn.label: Mr. Timothy M. Tymkovich
turn.text: In this case--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Thank you, Mr. Tymkovich.
The case is submitted.
